Authors:
Meriem Laidani, Maria Luisa Raimondo, Anna Maria D’Onghia,
Antonia Carlucci
Title:
Structure analysis of ribosomal IGS region of Phaeoacremonium
italicum as a study model
Keywords:
Phaeoacremonium italicum; intergenic spacer structure;
intraspecific variation; phylogenetic study
Abstract:
The increasing recognition of novel species in the
Phaeoacremonium genus and the recent taxonomic reassignment highlighted
the presence of paraphyly, intraspecific variation, and incongruence of
some Phaeoacremonium species by the employ of individual phylogenies
performed by actin and β-tubulin genes. The main aim of the present
study was to investigate the intergenic spacer (IGS) rDNA region of a
representative collection of 31 P. italicum strains and compare its
structure with that of closest related species, P. alvesii and P.
rubrigenum. The structural analysis of the IGS sequences allowed to
identify five categories of repeat elements organized in distinct
patterns. The morphological and microscopic analysis performed on all P.
italicum strains provided a description upgrated of P. italicum.
Phylogenetic tree constructed on IGS sequences and compared with that
obtained by combined analysis of β-tubulin and actin sequences
demonstrated that the IGS rDNA region could be a useful marker to
distinguish both intraspecific and interspecific variations, although
further molecular studies are needed to confirm if this region can help
to prevent the misidentifications and the introduction of vague species
boundaries in the Phaeoacremonium genus.
